title-group.article-title: Force control in a parallel manipulator through virtual foundations

abstract.p: An overwhelming controller provides robustness against uncertain parameters, disturbances and un-modelled dynamics. A simplified inverse dynamics model is used in the present paper to develop an overwhelming controller for a parallel manipulator (a Stewart platform), where the controller accommodates modelling uncertainties such as the simplifications made for development of the inverse model in order to improve the computational efficiency. Such a control strategy leads to good trajectory tracking accuracy in the presence of unknown disturbances. However, in addition to trajectory tracking performance, the controller for a Stewart platform should also be able to control or limit the interaction forces in applications such as robot assisted surgery and low-impact docking. The environmental forces can be accommodated during the interaction period by modulating the impedance at the interface of manipulator and environment through virtual flexible foundations. The positional error induced during the force control phase can be recovered during the free flight or idle phase. While this approach has been used successfully in the past to control serial manipulators, the closed loop kinematic architecture in a parallel manipulator introduces many difficulties. This paper proposes a modified overwhelming control scheme for parallel manipulators with compensations for interaction force control and positional error recovery. Bond graph modelling is used as an integrated model and controller development tool. Force controlled machining on a spherical surface, which is akin to a surgical operation, is considered as an example application of the developed control strategy. The simulation results from the bond graph model of the controlled Stewart platform are presented to demonstrate the performance of the developed hybrid position force controller.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Stewart platform1 or Stewart–Gough platform,2 a parallel manipulator, is a six-degrees-of-freedom mechanism with an upper movable end-effectors platform and a fixed base platform connected together by six hydraulically or electrically actuated prismatic legs. These legs are connected to the platforms through passive spherical and/or universal joints.3 Parallel manipulators are used in applications where structural rigidity and positional accuracy are important.4 They are used in different special purpose applications such as flight and vehicle simulators,1 tyre testing machines,2 mechanical wrists,5 machining and manufacturing,6 robot assisted surgery7 and low-impact docking.8

For the safe and reliable interaction of the manipulator with the environmental object, interaction forces have to be controlled. The manipulator should not provide more force than the safe load limits of the object with which the manipulator interacts. During trajectory tracking, force control is also necessary as any sort of misalignment may cause unexpected damage to either the manipulator or the object. Likewise, during robot assisted machining, the tool chatter phenomenon introduces dynamic forces at the tool–job interface and too much chatter can lead to bad surface finish. The need for force control in surgical operations does not need any elaboration. These are a few reasons for the implementation of a force control scheme in manipulators.

There are two types of force control schemes for manipulators: indirect and direct force control.9,10 In the indirect force control method, measurement of force is not required. In this method either stiffness or damping and mass at the contact point can be controlled. The exact model of the environmental object is necessary to apply this method. In the direct force control method, the exact model of the environmental object need not be known and only the error between the desired and measured force is required. This method is also known as the hybrid position force control scheme.11,12 A switching mode strategy for hybrid position force control to regulate the impact velocity and to dissipate the kinetic energy before the force control is considered in Assuncao and Schumacher.13 A force displaying device is developed in Takaiwa and Noritsugu14 using a pneumatic parallel manipulator to see compliance characteristics on the human skin where the force is controlled by using a compliance control method (indirect force control without using a force/moment sensor) and a disturbance observer. The contact point force is detected by the estimated force/moment and the target compliance is displayed according to the compliance control scheme. Force in a parallel link manipulator having velocity controlled hydraulic actuators can also be controlled by the generalized damping control method.15 The parallel approach,16 the virtual environment concept17 and operational space formulation18 are some of the other approaches for force control. Most often, the hybrid position force control is also integrated with a vision system.19

Impedance control at the contact point between the manipulator and the environment20–22 is one of the most robust and preferred approaches for direct force control. Impedance control by combining a virtual foundation with an overwhelming controller is another approach of hybrid position force control.23 Such a control scheme is derived from the physical model of the system, the inverse system, the overwhelming controller and the flexible foundation, where the physical foundation sub-system is transferred to the controller domain as a virtual sub-system after the initial design stage. The impedance at the manipulator and environment interface is modulated through a compensation gain. During the interaction period, the response trajectory suffers deviation from the command. This accumulated trajectory error is called amnesia and can be eliminated during the non-interaction period by another compensation loop implemented in the controller.

The energetic interactions between sub-systems of a system residing in different energy domains and the information exchange can be modelled in a unified manner by bond graph modelling.24–27 This modelling technique offers flexibility in modelling and handling large numbers of equations of complicated systems. Bond graph modelling is suitable for modelling large systems by creating sub-models and joining them to form the model of the integrated system. Bond graph modelling is especially suitable for modelling of multibody systems and systems having sensors, actuators, etc.,28,29 where multi-energetic non-linear interaction between the actuators and the system needs to be properly represented.30,31 Other applications of bond graph modelling in mechatronic systems32–36 include control,37–39 estimation, identification40 and fault detection.39,41

Very few research articles are available on force and trajectory control of the Stewart platform that consider realistic dynamic models.42–45 In fact, no model can be perfect. Inaccurate modelling can lead to unwanted performance of the model-based controller. One solution to this problem is the use of a robust controller which can accommodate minor modelling errors and uncertainties. An overwhelming controller provides robustness against unknown parameters, disturbances, un-modelled dynamics, etc. and gives better trajectory tracking accuracy in an uncertain environment. Therefore, an overwhelming controller was used in the present research for hybrid position force control with a compensation that accommodates environmental forces above the limit by modulating the impedance at the manipulator–environment interface during the interaction period. When the force interaction phase is completed, there is a difference between the reference trajectory position and the actual manipulator position. This difference (amnesia) is removed during the non-interaction period by another compensation established through an amnesia removal feedback loop. Thus, the controller attempts trajectory tracking during the non-interaction period and force control during the interaction period. This hybrid position force control scheme is guided by modulation of two separate compensation gains for each degree-of-freedom according to the measurements taken from the system.

The bond graph modelling approach has been followed herein due to the multi-energy domain nature of the electro-hydraulically controlled parallel manipulator. The forward model to be used in simulation and the inverse dynamics model to be used in controller are obtained by suitable causality assignments without changing the model structure. This benefit of bond graph modelling to work on a graphical level rather than in an equations level has been exploited in this research. Moreover, the bond graph approach has not only been used for system modelling but also for the development of model-based control laws, actuator sizing (estimation of inertial loads) and finally for simulation or virtual controller prototyping. Such approaches to integrated mechatronic system synthesis and analysis are being increasingly used in industry for design and product development lifecycle management.

The structure of the present paper is as follows. In the first step, the modelling of the force controller along with the concepts of flexible foundation, virtual foundation and overwhelming control scheme are discussed for a one-degree-of-freedom robot. The compensation gain modulation technique is developed in this phase. Then the movable platform of the parallel manipulator is modelled as a rigid body with six degrees-of-freedom. The Newton–Euler equation and coordinate and Euler angle transformations are used to construct a part of the bond graph model of the Stewart platform. In the next step, an inverse model of the Stewart platform is developed from a simplified forward model where reduced order or kinematic actuator models are used. The inverse model is used for implementation of the overwhelming control scheme where the simplifications of the inverse model are known to improve computational efficiency.46 Then the bond graph models of the four-way directional control valve and the hydraulic cylinder are developed and integrated with the bond graph model of the movable platform. Finally, the compensation loops for force control and amnesia removal are introduced to the overwhelming controller. As an example application, a hybrid position force controlled machining operation is discussed with some simulation results.

sec.title: Modelling of the Stewart platform
sec.p: The schematic representation of the Stewart platform is given in Figure 5, where the moving payload platform is supported by the fixed base through six variable length actuators. This is a six-degrees-of-freedom spherical–prismatic–spherical (6-SPS) mechanism. The fixed base coordinate system {XYZ} is placed at the point O with Y-axis perpendicular to the base plane. The movable platform coordinate system {xyz} is located at the centre G of the moving platform. All of the joints attached to the fixed and movable platform are spherical joints. A pair of legs is connected to a ball through two spherical joints and the ball in turn is held in a socket fixed to the moving platform in an arrangement similar to the Hexel Hexabot discussed by Merlet.53 The schematic representation given in Figure 5 does not show these details.

sec.title: Forward Stewart platform model without leg inertia
sec.p: The controller for the Stewart platform requires an inverse dynamics model of the Stewart platform.57,58 The inverse dynamics model may be based on various approaches such as the Newton–Euler approach and the principle of virtual work. When used in conjunction with an overwhelming controller, a simplified inverse model improves computational efficiency and real-time controller performance.46 Although only position control of a planar parallel manipulator is considered in the authors’ previous work,46 the same approach can be extended to hybrid position force control. The model is simplified by neglecting the parts of the actuator dynamics which lead to large numerical solution stiffness, i.e. the leg inertias and the hydraulic dynamics. The kinematic relations are, however, the same as that of the real system. The mismatch between the dynamics of the actual system and the simplified system can be thought of as disturbances and the overwhelming controller should overwhelm this mismatch or disturbance.

A simplified forward dynamics model will be constructed first to derive the lean inverse dynamics model. The inverse model is then derived from the forward model by swapping the inputs and outputs and reassigning the causalities. Note that the bicausality approach59,60 for system inversion cannot be applied here because the inputs and outputs are collocated.

The forward bond graph model of the Stewart platform without considering leg inertia and hydraulic actuation is shown in Figure 6. The movable platform is modelled as a six-degrees-of-freedom rigid body. The inertias MP, JPx, JPy and JPz are coupled by a pair of gyrator rings (Euler junction structure or EJS24,26,31,55), one for translational and the other for rotational motions, according to equations (8) to (13). The platform’s weight in the inertial frame acts on it in the non-inertial frame through CTF.55,56 The body fixed velocities of the points a, b and c are found according to equations (14) to (16) and are modelled in a vector bond graph form. The thick vertical line in this bond graph is used to merge (or split) scalar bonds to vector bonds. The modulus of the transformer element connected to two vector bonds is a matrix with constant coefficients (geometric parameters) that couples the linear velocities of points a, b and c to the linear and angular velocities of the platform. sec.title: Inverse Stewart platform and overwhelming controller model without leg inertia
sec.p: The inverse system model in the controller domain is a mirror reflection (left side flipped to right and vice versa) of the simplified model of the Stewart platform given in Figure 6. The model in Figure 6 is inverted by imposing the rate of change of leg lengths as inputs and forces generated in those legs as outputs. The inverse model is given in Figure 7. Stiff spring–damper combinations or pads (stiffness kp and damping rp) and joint flexibility (stiffness kj and damping rj) are included in the inverse model to avoid differential causalities and causal loops.46,61

caption.p: Bond graph model of the inverse system in the controller domain with overwhelming controller.

sec.p: The same parameters Mc, Kc and Rc are used in six independent overwhelming controllers, each associated with a degree-of-freedom, connected to the two CTF blocks, as shown in top left part of the model in Figure 7. The EATF block is used to compute the Euler angles. The plant parameters in the inverse model are shown with * superscript meaning that they are uncertain. The platform weight need not be modelled because it is uncertain and will be overwhelmed. The trajectory commands (reference velocities after revisions due to force control and amnesia removal compensation) are introduced to the overwhelming controller through ports numbered as 9 (within a circle).

The inputs to the inverse model with the overwhelming controller are the adjusted reference velocities (commands) and the rate of change of leg lengths measured from the actual platform or its model. The outputs from the inverse model with the overwhelming controller are the desired leg forces which have to be realized separately through hydraulic control. The left part of the inverse model concerns overwhelming control, the middle part represents rigid-body dynamics and the right part concerns actuator kinematics.

sec.title: Forward Stewart platform model with leg inertia
sec.p: Stewart platforms carrying heavy payloads are often hydraulically powered. A multi-axial vehicle test rig designed as a Stewart platform, which is driven by six servo hydraulic differential pressure cylinders, was developed at the Mechatronics Center Hannover (MZH)62 and can simulate realistic vehicle movements with six degrees-of-freedom in real time. The MZH platform can generate accelerations over 25g at frequencies up to 40 Hz. At such high acceleration and frequency levels, inertial effects are significant and therefore the actuator inertias are a significant factor in the actuator sizing.

In some hexapods, hydraulic power can be used for activities other than positioning of the platform. Hydraulically driven struts are used in production machines developed at TU Chemnitz.63 The ‘HexaBend’ developed at TU Chemnitz is a hydroforming device that can be used to bend tubes and profiles.64,65 Likewise, the flexible forming machine developed at TU Braunschweig66 is a hydraulically operated hexapod in which cascaded control with sliding mode is used to account for the uncertainties in the hydraulic actuator model.

A four-way directional control valve,67 shown in Figure 8(a), is used to control the hydraulic system. The load flow ports 1 and 2 are connected with the hydraulic cylinder. The bond graph model of the four-way directional control valve is shown in Figure 8(b). More details on the four-way directional control valve or servo valve model may be found elsewhere.42,46

caption.p: (a) Schematic of the four-way directional control valve and (b) its bond graph model.

sec.p: The driving efforts produced by the servo mechanism are taken out through ports 6 and 7 and are applied on the piston of the hydraulic cylinder. The flow rates through the modulated resistances are given by Merrit.67

The schematic of the hydraulic actuator is shown in Figure 9. The end 1 of the cylinder is fixed to the base platform and the other end 2 is connected with the moving platform. A proper dynamic model of the hydraulic cylinder is required for actuator sizing. The difficulties in modelling lie in estimating the dynamic loading due to leg inertia and friction forces.68

sec.p:
The cylinder and the piston are modelled as rigid bodies with each having six degrees-of-freedom. The modelling of the rigid-body dynamics is similar to that followed for the Stewart platform modelling. The inertial velocities of the fixed point 1 and the piston rod end point 2 are found in a manner similar to the process of finding the inertial velocities of the points a, b and c in the Stewart platform model. MTF elements with moduli µx, µy and µz are used to calculate the relative sliding velocity between the piston and the cylinder at a 0-junction according to equation (23). The contact point mechanics at points 3 and 4 are determined by equations (19) to (22). The movement of the piston depends upon the difference in pressures between both sides of the piston, which are determined in the sub-model for the four-way directional control valve and are interfaced through ports 6 and 7. The information of the force due to pressure difference, which is necessary for the force controller, is taken out through port 5. The information of the rate of deformation

Directly controlling the force in the hydraulic actuator for hybrid position force control is not a trivial task.71 The cylinder chamber pressure control with Coulomb-viscous friction prediction is difficult due to the large and somewhat uncertain piston friction force.68 However, when an overwhelming controller is used to take care of the modelling uncertainties and disturbances, a simple proportional–integral (PI) controller may be used for controlling the force or pressure in the hydraulic cylinder. The PI controller for the solenoid current in the four-way spool valve is shown in Figure 11. The information of the force acting on the piston is received from the model in Figure 10 through port 5. The inverse dynamics model with overwhelming controller (Figure 7) prescribes the set point for this controller. The controller output (through port 8) is used to activate the spool valve linear displacement in the bond graph model given in Figure 8(b).

sec.title: Force control and amnesia recovery
sec.p: The block diagram of the force controller with amnesia removal is shown in Figure 13. When the force interaction phase is completed there is a difference between the reference trajectory position and the actual manipulator position. This difference, which is called amnesia, is due to the reduction of impedance during force control. Amnesia or accumulated positional error needs to be removed before the next interaction to follow the reference trajectory during the non-interaction period.

sec.title: Example application: force controlled machining
sec.p: The integrated system for force control of a parallel manipulator is modelled by assembling the sub-models of the Stewart platform with leg inertia, the hydraulic piston–cylinder prismatic link, the four-way directional control valve, the PI controller for the solenoid, the inverse dynamics model with overwhelming controller and the force and amnesia compensators. The whole system can be broken down into two parts: integrated controller and the physical system. The integrated controller comprises the inverse dynamics model with overwhelming controller, the force and amnesia compensators and the solenoid current PI controller. The physical system comprises the Stewart platform, the hydraulic actuators, the four-way directional control valves and the sensors. In actual practice, the integrated controller will be interfaced with the physical system through necessary analogue to digital/digital to analogue converters and filters. However, a physical Stewart platform is not considered in the present paper and thus a model of the Stewart platform with its sensors and actuators is used to evaluate the hybrid position force control performance.

In a hypothetical scenario, it is considered that the robot tip has to move on the surface of a sphere representing the skin over the human skull to cut a patch PQRS on it. The points P, Q, R and S do not lie on the surface of the sphere, but somewhere inside it. Thus, some depth of cut (feed) is given to the robot tip before tracing the paths. All reference velocities are expressed in the inertial frame.

sec.p: The tool is assumed to move at constant angular speed ωref over the defined circular paths through translations along X-, Y- and Z-axes. The linear velocity commands for the overwhelming controller are computed accordingly and all angular velocity commands are kept zero. The velocity commands include the feed (depth of cut), motion over a circular path and tool retraction, reorientation and further feed for the next circular path.

Symbols software72 has been used for all model developments and simulations presented in this paper. This is an integrated platform for port-based modelling, simulation, animation, control system analysis, and fault detection and isolation system design. It can operate in both the Windows and Linux operating system environments. One of the major advantages of Symbols software is its implementation of polymorphic objects which allows template matching for varying boundary causalities. The software has many in-built capsules (sub-system objects) for basic engineering components. The equations of motion in symbolic form are derived by Symbols software from the bond graph model of the system. Symbols software has an in-built simulator module in which the equations derived from the bond graph model can be directly simulated. It is further possible to export the equations or the model in various forms like S-function for MATLAB/Simulink, C++ source code for user written solvers, etc. In this paper, the in-built solver of Symbols software has been used to directly simulate the bond graph model.

sec.title: Trajectory tracking performance
sec.p: The reference trajectory PQRS along with projections on the X–Y, X–Z and Y–Z planes are shown in Figure 14(a). It is assumed that initially the tool touches the sphere. A velocity in the inertial Y-direction is given so that the tool penetrates into the sphere through a distance of 5 mm, which is the depth of cut. Then the tool moves along a circular path PQ, retracts by 5 mm and rotates about the inertial Z-axis through an angle of 90°. The tool orientation is done by another motor mounted on the platform. Then the tool again penetrates into the sphere through a distance of 5 mm in the inertial X-direction, which is another depth of cut. Then the tool moves along a circular path QR. Similarly, paths RS and SP are traced.

caption.p: (a) Reference trajectory during force control and (b) the response trajectory without force control.

sec.p:
For robust trajectory tracking, gain parameters α and
ς
are chosen to be 50 and 10−6, respectively. Thus, the tool moves without force accommodation. The response trajectory of the tool tip is shown in Figure 14(b). It is found that the tracking behaviour is satisfactorily acceptable for the response (Figure 14(b)) and it can be improved with higher value of gain parameter α, but with reduced computational speed, i.e. reduced allowable angular speed ωref.

The plots of reference positions (integrations of reference velocities) and actual X-, Y- and Z-displacements versus time are shown in Figure 15(a) to (c), respectively. The position error of the target points in Y-direction is comparatively larger than that in X- and Z-directions. But the percentage of tracking errors for X, Y and Z motions (not shown) lies within ±2%. Further accurate results are obtained when larger overwhelming control gain and smaller force compensation gains are used. The position errors are much less as the position errors of the actuators (parallel manipulators) are not accumulated compared with the serial manipulators where positional errors are compounded.

caption.p: (a) Plot of reference and actual X-displacement versus time, (b) plot of reference and actual Y-displacement versus time and (c) plot of reference and actual Z-displacement versus time without force control.

sec.title: Force control
sec.p:
For direct hybrid position force control, a force/torque sensor is mounted on the moving platform and this sensor measures the interaction force/torque between the tool and the environment. This interaction force is compared with the limiting value of the force specified in the force controller and the compensation gain
ς
i
in the controller domain is used to modulate the impedance at the interaction point.

In the simulated scenario, the force is controlled in the inertial Y-direction when the tip of the manipulator moves from point P to point Q and from point R to point S. Similarly, the force is controlled in the inertial X-direction when the tip of the manipulator moves from point Q to point R and from point S to point P. The torques are not controlled in the present application, although in principle they can be controlled and the model has provisions for that. The response trajectory during force control without amnesia removal is shown in Figure 16(a). In this case, the tool does not reach the starting point at the end of the cycle.

caption.p: (a) Response trajectory during force control without amnesia removal and (b) response trajectory during force control with amnesia removal.

sec.p: The plots of reference and actual X- and Y-displacements versus time during force control without amnesia removal are shown in Figure 17(a) and (b), respectively. For the initial 5 mm depth of cut in Y-direction, the tool penetrates into the sphere until the force limit of 5 N is reached. After that force limit, the foundation starts sinking.

caption.p: (a) Plot of reference and actual X-displacement versus time and (b) plot of reference and actual Y-displacement versus time during force control without amnesia removal.

sec.p: There is a sharp difference between command and response of Y-displacement during force control along Y-direction when the tool moves along a circular path PQ but there is no deviation in X-displacement for this zone. Then the tool retracts and rotates about the inertial Z-axis through an angle of 90°. The tool again penetrates into the sphere for 5 mm feed in the inertial X-direction until the limit force of 5 N is reached. There is a sharp difference between command and response of X- as well as Y-displacements during force control along X-direction when the tool moves along a circular path QR. Similar phenomena happen when the tool moves from point R to point S (force control along Y-direction) and moves from point S to point P (force control along X-direction). During the entire cycle, it is observed that there is an appreciable difference between command and response both for X- and Y-displacements. This can be overcome by the amnesia removal loop.

The response trajectory during force control with amnesia removal is shown in Figure 16(b). Plots of reference and actual X- and Y-displacements versus time during force control with amnesia removal are shown in Figure 18(a) and (b), respectively.

caption.p: (a) Plot of reference and actual X-displacement versus time and (b) plot of reference and actual Y-displacement versus time during force control with amnesia removal.

sec.p: It is seen from Figure 18(b) that force is controlled in the inertial Y-direction during the interaction period when the tip of the Stewart platform moves from point P to point Q and after that amnesia is removed during the non-interaction period so that response follows the command. Similarly, it is seen from Figure 18(a) that force is controlled in the inertial X-direction during the interaction period when the tip of the Stewart platform moves from point Q to point R and after that amnesia is removed during the non-interaction period so that response follows the command. Similar phenomena happen when the tip moves from point R to point S and from point S to point P. It is clear from Figure 18(a) and (b) that after completion of one cycle the tip reaches the starting point.

The plots of interaction forces along X- and Y-directions versus time are shown in Figure 19(a). It is seen that initially the force developed exceeds the limiting value of force by a small amount due to the inertia of the moving platform. Although the tool initially touches the environment, the force developed exceeds the limiting value of force by a small amount as the feed rate is very high (10 cm/s). After that the force is controlled around the limiting value of force (5 N) during the interaction period in both inertial X- and Y-directions. The plots of shrinkages δs along X- and Y-directions versus time are shown in Figure 19(b). This shrinkage is the accumulated position error or amnesia during the interaction period and it is recovered in the non-interaction period.

caption.p: (a) Plot of interaction forces along X- and Y-directions versus time and (b) plot of shrinkages along X- and Y-directions versus time.

sec.p: Note that shrinkage is always negative in the Y-direction because the tool always encounters reaction force from the object or environment (sphere) in the vertical downward direction whereas shrinkage in the X-direction is negative for some interaction period (while cutting along path QR) and positive for the other interaction period (while cutting along path SP). The forces are minimal in the Z-direction and are not controlled because cutting forces are assumed to be small compared with the feed or thrust forces. It is possible to create a more realistic tool–environment interaction model with forces and moments acting on the tool in X-, Y- and Z-directions. The developed inverse model of the Stewart platform with force and amnesia compensation loops can accommodate forces and torques for all six degrees-of-freedom.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Bond graph implementation of an overwhelming controller along with a hybrid position force control strategy for a hydraulically driven six-degrees-of-freedom Stewart platform has been considered in the present paper. A simple and computationally efficient inverse model without considering the detailed actuator dynamics is used to implement both overwhelming and force control strategies. The amnesia or positional error accumulated during force control is eliminated during the non-interaction period so that the response follows the command before the next interaction phase. The force control strategy was evaluated by considering a machining/surgical operation on a spherical surface. The forces are controlled in different directions. The interaction forces exceed their specified thresholds temporarily during the initial contact or feed period. This excess force is due to the heavy feed rate and inertia of the parallel manipulator. The loss of position information during force control is recovered properly through a heuristic amnesia removal scheme.

In this paper, the inverse dynamics model with overwhelming controllers and force and amnesia compensation loops has been integrated with a model of a Stewart platform. This controller can be integrated with a real Stewart platform for experimental verification. The modular model developed here clearly separates the numerical (computerized control) domains and the physical domains.

The developed integrated modelling approach also allows for actuator sizing for specific applications. The reader is referred to Bera et al.46 for a bond graph model-based analysis of the contribution of leg inertia to leg forces in a planar parallel manipulator. Although the results pertaining to the Stewart platforms actuator dynamics are not discussed here, the model does indeed indicate the limits on the actuator forces, slew rates (response time), etc. It is well known that besides the payload and interaction forces, the inertial forces due to leg and platform inertia and friction forces can be major contributors to leg forces during high speed operation of the Stewart platform. Thus, the model developed here is not just useful for controller synthesis and tuning, but also for holistic mechatronic system design.
